webTitle: Energy bills push UK inflation to nine-month high

fields.bodyText: The annual rate of inflation rose for the first time in five months in February as dearer energy bills added to the cost of living. The Office for National Statistics said inflation as measured by the consumer prices index stood at 2.8% last month, up from 2.7% and the highest for nine months. Officials blamed the increase on the latest hikes in domestic energy tariffs from the UK's major suppliers and a rise in petrol prices. Housing costs rose by 0.5% between January and February due to the increase in domestic gas and electricity bills, while a 4p a litre increase in the cost of petrol added 1.2% to transport prices. With wage increases running at little more than 1% on average, the upward nudge to the inflation rate will add to the squeeze on consumer spending power and dampen growth prospects over the coming months. Inflation as measured by the CPI has been running above its 2% target for the past four years but the Bank of England believes it will rise further to around 3% during 2013. Threadneedle Street expects inflation then to ease back and return to target in 2014, although there is speculation in the City that George Osborne may signal possible changes to the Bank's monetary policy mandate in Wednesday's budget to allow its nine-strong monetary policy committee greater leeway to boost the UK's struggling economy. The ONS on Tuesday published two new measures of inflation to run alongside the government's preferred measure – the CPI. CPIH, which excludes housing costs from the consumer prices index, rose from 2.5% to 2.6% last month, while the RPIJ – a measure designed to smooth out disparities between the consumer prices index and the retail prices index – fell from 2.7% to 2.6%. The Treasury took comfort from the fact that inflation was in line with City expectations and said it had almost halved since its recent peak of 5.2%. But James Knightley, economist at ING, said the recent rise in producer prices suggested more inflation was in the pipeline. "Consequently, household incomes remain squeezed by the fact wages are still failing to keep pace with the cost of living with Wednesday's budget unlikely to offer any significant respite."

webTitle: FTSE under pressure on mining downgrade and Cyprus worries, while Sainsburys climbs

fields.standfirst: Investors cautious as brokers negative on commodities sector and Cyprus parliament set to vote on bailout
fields.body:
Mining shares have led the market lower after a series of downgrades, while investors remain nervous ahead of the Cypriot parliament voting on the controversial bailout deal agreed early on Saturday.

Citigroup cut its forecasts on iron ore prices, while Goldman Sachs cut its outlook for mining stocks on concerns about slowing global economic growth. Goldman cut its recommendation on Rio Tinto, down 144p to £31.33, from neutral to sell and on BHP Billiton, 72p lower at £19.82, from buy to neutral.

Other miners were also weaker, including precious metals group Fresnillo, down 70p at £13.86 after Deutsche Bank cut from hold to sell, and Vedanta Resources, 30p lower at £11.02.

Banks were also under pressure on worries about the Cyprus situation, where savers are threatened with a £5bn hit on their deposits. Barclays is down 5.65p at 300.3p while Lloyds Banking Group has lost 0.55p to 49.3p. Royal Bank of Scotland has slipped 4p to 293.3p despite Investec moving from sell to hold.

Arm, the chip designer, has fallen 25.5p to 895p after the surprise departure of chief executive Warren East. Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, said:

Share price reaction is normal (it will have generated some uncertainty), but perhaps not as negative as some might have expected, even though earlier than expected, with internal replacement Simon Segars being the current President (and thus board member), as well as head of the key Intellectual Property division. Having been at the company since 1991, investors envisage a continuation of the existing strategy and thus negligible management-change risk.

Elsewhere J Sainsbury is leading the risers, up 9.9p at 375.1p after its fourth quarter like for like sales beat forecasts, rising 3.6% excluding fuel, helped by strong growth in online and convenience stores.

Vodafone is 3.05p higher at 188p after Jefferies raised its target price from 155p to 174p with a hold rating. There has been much speculation that Vodafone could sell its stake in its US joint venture Verizon Wireless, or indeed be a target for a full takeover from its US partner. Jerry Dellis at Jefferies said:

Four days with Vodafone investor relations last week revealed (1) no hint of advanced discussions with Verizon and (2) European acquisition ambitions downplayed. While we view a merger with Verizon as the economically rational endgame for both parties, currently both view time as an ally. As speculation subsides, attention will return to the more difficult topic of Vodafone's May guidance-setting. Revised 2014 free cash flow now £4.6bn, 8% below consensus.
While there is a body of thought that a tax-effective Verizon Wireless spin/sale is possible, our reading of the body language of Vodafone management is that they remain highly sceptical. Consequently, in our view, a Verizon-Vodafone merger is the rational endgame, albeit with strict boundary conditions to keep it compelling for each side. At a hypothetical 220p per Vodafone share, funded 50:50 with debt and Verizon stock, we show that mid-term earnings per share accretion at the Verizon level matches up closely against around 20% upside offered to Vodafone shareholders.

The FTSE 100 is currently down 24.92 at 6433.00, as UK inflation hit a nine-month high in February. Annual consumer price inflation rose to 2.8% from 2.7%, pushed up by oil prices. But the figure was in line with forecasts.

webTitle: Osborne must resist hawks' call for defence cash

fields.standfirst: Pressure is mounting on chancellor to keep his military-minded MPs on a short leash and top up the aid budget
fields.body:
Pressure is mounting on George Osborne to keep his military-minded MPs on a short leash and top up the aid budget. It needs to rise from £8.6bn in 2011 to £11.3bn next year to fulfil Britain's pledge to the UN to donate 0.7% of Gross National Income.

More than 100 economists followed up a letter last week from leaders of the UK's biggest companies urging the chancellor to stay the course. There are also 170 charities pushing the benefits of aid, especially its potential to build self-sufficiency through agriculture and infrastructure investment.

It must be welcomed that the chancellor appears ready to stick to his guns and not siphon money away to spend on various armaments – as many Tory supporters wish – but he should heed the warnings of those who argue that civil servants in the department for international development, forced to rush to meet spending targets, could invest unwisely.
